title: Rashi on Genesis
text: Rabbi Yitzchak said: [God] could have begun the Torah only from 'This month shall be to you' (Exodus 12:2), which is the first mitzvah (precept) which Israel was commanded. So what is the reason that [God] began with 'In the beginning'? Because of [the idea expressed in the verse]: '[God] has declared to His people the power of His works, in order to give them the heritage of the nations' (Psalms 111:6). Thus, should the nations of the world say to Israel: 'You are robbers, having conquered the lands of the seven [Canaanite] nations [by force],' [Israel] can say to them: 'The whole earth belongs to the Holy Blessed One; He created it and gave it to whomever He saw fit. By His will He gave it to [the Canaanite seven nations], and by His will He took it from them and gave it to us.'

In the beginning (Bereishit), created: This text says nothing if not 'interpret me' - as the Rabbis, of blessed memory, expounded upon it: [God created the world] for the sake of the Torah which is called "the beginning (reishit) of [God's] way" (Proverbs 8:22), and for the sake of Israel who were called "the beginning (reishit) of [God's] grain" (Jeremiah 2:3). And if you are coming to explain it according to its simple meaning, explain it thus: "At the beginning of the creation of the heavens and the earth, and the earth was chaos and void and darkness... God said, 'let there be light.'" And [the verse] is not coming to teach the order of the creation, to tell us that [the heavens and the earth] came first; since if it was coming to teach this, it should have written, "barishona (at first), He created the heavens, etc.;" as there is no [usage of the word,] reishit (beginning of), in the Bible except when it is connected to the word that is after it, such as "In the beginning of the reign of Yehoiyakim" (Jeremiah 26:1); "the beginning of his kingdom" (Genesis 10:10); "the beginning of your grain" (Deuteronomy 18:4). Here too, you would say, "In the beginning of when God created, etc.," like "In the beginning of His creating." And similar to it is (Hosea 1:2), "At the beginning (betechillat) of God's speaking to Hoshea," which is to say the beginning of the Holy One's, blessed be He, speech to Hoshea, "and God said to Hoshea, etc." And if you will [insist] that this is coming to teach that these were created first, and its explanation is, "In the beginning of everything, God created [the heavens and the earth] - and you have [other] verses that abbreviate their language and omit a word, such as (Job 3:9), "For He did not close the doors of my womb" and it does not explain who is the closer; and such as (Isaiah 8:4), "he will carry off the wealth of Damascus" and it does not explain who will carry it off; and such as (Amos 6:12), "for will they plow with cattle," and it does not explain it [to say], "for will people plow with cattle;" and such as (Isaiah 46:10), "who tells the beginning (reishit) from the end," and it does not explain it [to say], "who tells from the beginning of a matter, the end of the matter" - if so, you should wonder about [what] you [are saying], since behold, the waters were earlier, since behold, it is written, "and the spirit of God was hovering upon the waters," and [yet] the text did not reveal when the creation of water had been, but you have learned that the waters preceded the earth. And also, that the heavens were created of water and fire [and so preceded the heavens]. Perforce, then, the verse is not teaching the order of what came earlier and what came later at all .

God (Elohim - God's name traditionally associated with His trait of strict judgment) created: And it did not state, 'the Lord' (God's name traditionally associated with His trait of mercy). Since, at first, it came up in [His] thought to create [the world] with the trait of strict justice, [and] He saw that the world [would] not [be able to] exist; [so] He brought the trait of mercy in front and combined it with the trait of strict justice. Concerning this is it written (Genesis 2:4), "on the day that the Lord, God, made earth and heavens."
Chaos (tohu) and void (bohu): Tohu is an expression of wonder and desolation that a person would wonder and be bewildered about the bohu of it.
Tohu: Estordision (confusion) in [Old French].
Bohu: An expression of emptiness and desolation.
On the face of the deep: On the face of the waters that were on the earth.

And the spirit of God was hovering: The Throne of Glory was standing in the air and floating over the face of the waters by the breath of the mouth of the Holy One, blessed be He, and his pronouncement - like a dove hovering over a nest. Acoveter (to cover) in [Old French].

And God saw the light that it was good, and He separated: Also here, we need the words of the aggadah (homiletical teachings): He saw it, [and saw] that it was not proper for the wicked to use it; so He separated it for the righteous in the future. And according to its simple meaning, explain it as follows: He saw it, that it was good, and it was unseemly that [light] and darkness should serve in a mishmash; so He established for this one its boundary by day, and for that one its boundary by night.

One day: According to the order [language] of the section, it should have written, "the first day," as it is written with the other days - second, third, fourth - [so] why is is written, "one?" Because the Holy One, blessed be He, was one in His world, as the angels were not created until the second day. Thus is it explained in Bereishit Rabbah 3:8.

"Let there be a firmament:" Let the firmament harden. Since, even though the heavens were created on the first day, they were still wet, and they solidified on the second from the scolding of the Holy One, blessed be He, in his saying, "Let there be a firmament." And this is what is written (Job 26:11), "The pillars of the heavens were shaking" the entire first day and on the second, "they were astounded by his scolding," like a person that is confounded and stops by the scolding of someone threatening him.

"In the midst of the waters:" In the middle of the waters, as there is a space between the higher waters and the firmament just like there is [one] between the firmament and the waters on the earth. Behold, you have learned that they are suspended by the word of the King.
And God made the firmament: He arranged it in its position; and that is its making, as per (Deuteronomy 21:12), "and she made her nails."

From over (me'al) the firmament: It does not state, over (al) the firmament, but rather, from over the firmament; since they are suspended in the air. And why does it not state, "it was good," on the second day? Because the work of the water was not completed until the third day; and behold, He [only] started it on the second [day], and something that is not finished is not in its fullness and goodness. And on the third [day], when the work of the water was completed and He started a different work and completed it, He repeated "it was good" twice on it - one for the finishing of the work of the second [day] and one for the finishing of the work of that day.

And God called the firmament, heavens (shamayim): Lift waters (sa mayim); over there are waters (sham mayim; fire and water (esh oumayim) that He mixed together, one with the other, and made heavens from them.
"Let the waters gather:" They were spread over the face of the whole earth and he gathered them in the Okiyanus (the Ocean), which is the largest of all the seas.

He called seas: And is it not [all] one sea? Except that the taste of fish that comes up [from the sea] in Akko (Acre) is not the same as the taste of the fish that comes up [from the sea] in Espamia.

"Let the earth bring forth grass (desheh esev):" Desheh is not an expression of esev and esev is not an expression of desheh, and [so] the expression of Scripture could not have [been], taasiv haarets [exchanging one word for the other]. Since types of deshaim are divided, each one by itself is called a certain esev. And it is not common parlance to say a certain desheh, since desheh is an expression of covering the earth when it is full of grasses.

"Let the earth bring forth:" Let it be filled and covered with a mantle of herbs. In [Old French], desheh is called erbediz [a collective of herbs] all of them in a mixture, whereas each root individually is called esev.
"That produces seed:"That its seed should grow in it, so as to sow from it in a different place.

"Fruit trees:" That the taste of the tree should be like the taste of the fruit. And [the earth] did not do so, but rather (verse 14) “the earth gave forth, etc. trees producing fruit,” and the trees [themselves] were not fruit. Therefore, when man was cursed because of his iniquity, it [the earth] too was remembered for its iniquity and was cursed.
"The seed of which is in it:" These are the pits [seeds] of every fruit, from which the tree grows when it is planted.

And the earth brought forth, etc.: Even though "according to its species" is not stated concerning the grasses when they were commanded, [nonetheless] they heard that the trees were commanded thus; and they brought up an a fortiori argument (kal vechomer) regarding themselves, as is explained in the aggadah (homiletical teachings) in Chapter Shechitat Chullin (Chullin 60a).

"Let there be luminaries:" They were created from the first day; and on the fourth day, He commanded them to be suspended in the heavens. And so [too], all of the issue of the heavens and the earth were created from the first day, and each one was affixed on the day that was decreed about it. That is why it is written (verse 1), "et (a Hebrew preposition, which can either proceed a direct object or mean 'with,' and so, is often seen as indicating additional meaning) hashamayim (the heavens)," in order to include their issue,”and "et haarets (the earth)," in order to include its issue.

"Let there be luminaries:" Luminaries (meorot) is written [in its incomplete spelling] lacking the [letter,] vav. [It can thus also be read as the word, curses (ma'arot)], since it is the day of the curse that babies get sick with croup. And that is what we learned (Sofrim 17:5), “on the fourth day [Wednesdays], they would fast so that the babies would not get sick with croup.”

"To separate between the the day and the night:" [This happened] after the first light was hidden away, but during the seven days of Creation, the first light and the first darkness served - whether by day or whether by night.

"And they will be for signs:" When the luminaries are eclipsed, it is a bad sign for the world, as it is stated (Jeremiah 10:2), "from the signs of the sky do not fear;" [meaning that only] when you do the will of the Holy One, blessed be He, do you not need to fear from calamity.

"And for appointed times:" [It was stated] based on the future, since in the future, Israel would be commanded regarding the festivals; and those would be [determined based] on the appearance of the [new] moon.
"And for days:" The service of the sun is half a day and the service of the moon is [for the duration] of its [other] half; behold that is a full day.

"And for years:" At the end of 365 days, they complete their orbit through the twelve constellations that serve them - and that is a year. (And they go back and begin to rotate around the circuit like their first trajectories a second time.)
"And they shall be for luminaries:" They will also serve in this way - that they will illuminate the world.
The great luminaries: They were created equal; and the moon was reduced, since it complained and said, "it is impossible for two kings to use one crown."
And the stars: Given that He reduced the moon, he increased its hosts to appease it.
"Living souls:" That has life in it.

"Swarming thing (sherets):" Every living thing that is not very high from the ground is called sherets: among flying creatures, such as flies; among insects, such as ants, beetles and worms; and among the [four legged] creatures, such as the weasel, the mouse, the lizard, and their like; and all of the fish.

[Sea] monsters: These are large fish in the sea. And in the words of the aggadah (homiletical teachings), it is the Leviathan and his spouse - that He created male and female, and killed and cured the female for the righteous ones [to eat] in the future; since if they would be fruitful and multiply, the world would not be able to stand in front of them.
The living souls: That has life in it.

And He blessed them: Because [man] eliminates and hunts from them and [he] eats them, the blessing was needed. And [so,] also the animals needed a blessing, except that because of the snake that would receive a curse in the future; for that reason He did not bless them, so that it would not be included.
"Be fruitful:" It is an expression of fruit; which means to say, "make fruit."
"And multiply:" If He had only said, "be fruitful," one would have given birth to one and no more; and [so] comes "and multiply," so that one [can] give birth [to] many.
"Let the earth bring forth:" That is what I explained (verse 14) - that everything was created from the first day and it was only necessary to bring them out.
"Living souls:" That has life in it.

"And crawling things (remes):" These are the creeping things, which are low and crawl upon the earth [and] appear as if they are dragging along, because their movement is not discernible. All expressions of remes and sherets in our language are conmovres (crawling things) in [Old French].
And he made: He refined them to be in their desired state and in their [full] stature.

"Let us make man:" We learn of the humility of the Holy One, blessed be He, from here. Since man was in the image of the angels and they would [hence] be jealous of him, therefore He took counsel with them. And when He judges kings, He consults with His retinue [of angels]; since thus we find with Achav, who was told by Micha (I Kings 22:19), "I have seen the Lord sitting on His throne, and the entire host of the heavens was standing over Him, on His right and on His left." And is there right and left in [His presence]? Rather [the intention is that], these were going to the right to find merit and those were going to the left to find guilt. And so [too] (Daniel 4:14), "The decree is in the word of the wakeful ones and in the statement of the holy ones is the proposition." Also here did He consult with His retinue and get their agreement: He said to them, "there are in the higher ones like my likeness, if there are not in the lower ones like my likeness, behold, there will be jealousy within the work of creation."

"Let us make man:" Even though they did not help Him in [man's] formation and there is [now] room for the heretics to rebel, the verse did not stop from teaching proper behavior and the trait of humility - that the greater should consult with and get the agreement of the lesser. And had it written, "I will make man," we would not learn that He spoke with His court, but rather [only] with Himself. And the answer to the heretics is written at its side: "And God created (yivra which is singular) man," and it did not write yivrau (plural).
"In our image:" In our mold.
"According to our likeness:" To understand and to have insight.

"And they shall have dominion (yirdu) over the fish of the sea:" This expression contains [both] an expression of dominion (ridui) and an expression of descent (yeridah). [Hence, it is saying that] if [man] merits [it], he will have dominion over the animals and the beasts; if he does not merit [it], he will become lowly in front of them and the animals will rule over him.

And God created man in His image: In the mold that was made for him - since everything was created with a proclamation, but he was created manually, as it is written, (Psalms 139:5) "and you placed your palm upon me." He was made with an imprint like a coin that is made with an impression that is called coin (coin) in [Old French]. And so it states (Job 38:14), "The seal changes like clay."
In the image of God, did He create him: It explains to you that this image which was prepared for him is the image of the facsimile of his Creator.

Male and female, He created them: And later it states (Genesis 2:21), "And He took one of his ribs, etc." There is a midrash aggadah [that explains] that He created him with two faces at the first creation and afterwards divided him. And the simple explanation is [that] here it is telling you that both of them were created on the sixth day and it does not explain how their creation [happened], and it explains [it] to you in a different place.

"And subdue it:" It is missing a [letter,] vav (and so could be read as kavshah, which means subdues her); to teach you that the male subdues the female from being unrestrained. And also, it is to teach you that since it is his way to conquer, the man is commanded in being fruitful and multiplying, and not the woman.

"To you shall they be for food and for all of the animals of the earth:" The verse equated them with the beasts and the animals concerning food, and [so] did not permit Adam and his wife to kill a creature and eat meat. Rather, only all green herbs would they all eat together. And when the sons of Noach arrived (after the flood), He permitted meat to them, as it is stated (below, Genesis 9:3), "every crawling thing, which is alive, etc. like the green herb" which I permitted to Adam, "have I given you everything."

The sixth day: It added [the letter,] hay, to the word, sixth, (making it read, the sixth day, whereas all of the other days were not preceded with a hay), to say that He made a condition with [the acts of creation], that [the creation] was on condition that Israel would accept the five (which is the numerical equivalent of hay) books of the Torah. A different [explanation]: The sixth day - they were all dependent and waiting until the sixth day; that is the sixth of Sivan, which was [the day] prepared for the giving of the Torah.

(Other editions: Since on the sixth day of Sivan, on which Israel received the Torah, the entire creation was strengthened; and it was considered as if the world was created then. And that is what is meant by the sixth day with a hay; that the day [referred to] was the sixth of Sivan.)

And God completed on the seventh day: Rabbi Shimon said: [A human being of] flesh and blood, who cannot [exactly] know his times and his moments, must add from the profane to the holy [i.e., he must add some time to the Sabbath.] The Holy One, blessed be He, Who knows His times and His moments [exactly], entered it [the Sabbath] within a hairbreadth, and it therefore appeared as if He completed it [His work] on that day. Another explanation: What was the world lacking? Rest. The Sabbath came, and so came rest. The work was completed and finished. — [from Gen. Rabbah 10:9]

He gathered dust from all the land from the four directions, so that in every place he would die in, the earth would receive him for burial. Alternatively, he took his dust from the place upon which it says, "An altar of earth you shall make for Me" (Exodus 20), He said, 'If only it may serve as atonement for him, and he may be able to stand'.

"It is not good for man to be alone:" That they should not say that there are two powers: the Holy One, blessed be He, is unique in the upper beings and has no mate; and this one is unique in the lower beings and has no mate.
"A help opposite him (kenegdo):" If he merits [it], a help. If he does not merit [it], against him (an alternative meaning of kenegdo) to fight.

"and they were not embarrassed". Because they were not aware of [the concept of] (lit. path of) modesty [which requires the ability] to distinguish between good and evil. And although he was given [enough] awareness to name all the animals, he was not given the Evil Inclination until he ate from the tree and [only then] was imbued with the Evil Inclination and became aware of the difference between good and evil.
And…were opened: Scripture is referring to wisdom, and not to actual vision, and the end of the verse proves this. — [from Gen. Rabbah 19:7]

and they knew that they were naked: Even a blind man knows when he is naked! What then is the meaning of “and they knew that they were naked” ? They had one commandment in their possession, and they became denuded of it.

(8) And they heard- there are many medrashic agadot, and they have already been organized in Bereishit Raba and in other Medrashot. I have only come to (arrive at or help explain) pshuto shel mikra, the plain meaning of the text, and to (bring at times) the agadic works that settle the words of the Torah, each word in its place.

This one will provide ease for us: The toil of our hands will be eased. Until Noach arrived nobody had a plow, and he created one for them. The land would produce thistles and thorns when wheat was planted, as a result of the curse of Adam, but in the times of Noach this was eased. And that is "will provide ease for us" - will be eased from us. And if you do not interpret in this manner, the meaning of the word does not align with his name, and instead he should be called Menachem.

the sons of the nobles. Another explanation: בְּנֵי הָאֱלֹהִים are the princes who go as messengers of the Omnipresent. They too mingled with them. Every אֱלֹהִים in Scripture is an expression of authority, and the following proves it (Exod. 4:16): “And you shall be to him as a lord (לֵאלֹהִים)”; (ibid. 7:1): “See, I have made you a lord (אֶלֹהִים).”

"In his generation..." -  (Sanhedrin 109) Some of our rabbis interpret this as praise, meaning, all the more so, if he had been in a generation filled with righteous people, he would have been even more righteous.  And there are those who interpret it as criticism, meaning, if he had been in Abraham's generation, he would not have been thought of as anything special.
"Noah walked with God..." - And with Abraham it says (Genesis 24): "Walk before Me!"  Noah needed support to keep him up, but Abraham would strengthen himself and walk righteously on his own.

Make yourself an ark of: Salvation and relief are abundant before God - so why should God task him with this construction project? So that when the people of the generation of the Flood saw him busy with it for 120 years and they asked him: "What are you doing?" He could respond to them: "In the future, the Holy One of Blessing will bring a flood upon the earth" - and thus perhaps they would repent.
Gopher wood: That is its name. And why of this material? [Hinting] at the name of brimstone ("gofrith"), which they were decreed to be erased with.

"for I have seen that you are righteous": And it doesn't say "perfectly righteous" [cf. Genesis 6:9]. From here [we learn] that we say some of the praise of a man to his face, and all of it not to his face.
Pure: That will be "pure" [i.e. kosher] for Israel in the future, teaching us that Noah learned the Torah.
Seven and seven: So as to sacrifice from them-- the sacrifice upon exiting.
"Before the flood waters..." - Even Noah had little faith. He believed and didn't believe that the flood would come, and he didn't enter the ark until the water was pushing him in.
In the second month: Rabbi Elazar says this means [the month of] Bitter Heshvan, Rabbi Yehoshua says this means [the month of] Iyar

"And Elokim remembered" - This name (Elokim) is associated with the attribute of (strict) Judgement. (God' interaction with the world was) switched to the attribute of mercy through the teffilot of the righteous, as the wickedness of the wicked transform (God's interaction with the world from) the attribute of mercy to the attribute (strict) judgement as it is stated "and Hashem saw that the wickedness of man had become great...", "and Hashem said, I will erase..." and Hashem is the name associated with the attribute of mercy.
"Go, yourself" - For your benefit, and for your own good, and there I will make you into a great nation.  Here you will not merit children.  And what's more, I will let the world know all about you.

"and you will be a blessing". The [rights to give] blessings are given into your hand. Until now, [the rights to give blessings] were in my hands. I blessed Adam, Noah, and You. From now on, you will bless whoever you want. Another understanding [of the idea behind "and you will be a blessing"]: "and I will make you into a great nation" [refers] to that which is said [in the Shmoneh Esreh prayer] "the God of Abraham". "and I will bless you" [refers] to that which is said [in the Shmoneh Esreh prayer] "the God of Isaac". "and I will make your name great" [refers] to that which is said [in the Shmoneh Esreh prayer] "the God of Jacob". [You might think that the first paragraph of the Shmoneh Esreh] should be concluded [with a blessing formulated to include mention of] all [of the forefathers], [but really the Torah] says "and YOU will be a blessing", [meaning] [the nation of Israel] will conclude [first paragraph of the Shmoneh Esreh] with you, but not with them (i.e. the other forefathers).

"And be blessed through you" - there are many Legends and Traditions on this idea and this is their essence: A man will say to his son 'Be like Avraham'.  And this is the meaning of all expressions of 'be blessed through you' in Scripture.  And the proof is (Genesis 48) 'Through you shall Israel be blessed, May God make you like Ephraim and Menasheh'.

"that they 'made' in Haran"-they brought them under the wings of the Shechina (God's presence); Abraham would convert the men and Sarah would convert the women, the Torah writes it as if they 'created' them (that's why it says 'made')...

Continually traveling: lit. going and traveling. [He traveled] in intervals, staying here for a month or more, traveling from there, and pitching his tent elsewhere. And all his travels were southward, to go to the south of the Land of Israel, and that is to the direction of Jerusalem, which is in the territory of Judah, who took [his portion] in the south of the Land of Israel, to Mount Moriah, which was his [Judah’s] heritage. (Gen. Rabbah 39:16).

And the birds of prey: Heb. הָעַיִט. This is a bird, and [it is called עַיִט] because it swoops down [עָט] and seeks the carcasses. Like (Job 9:26): “to swoop upon food,” and like (I Sam. 15:19): “and you flew (וַתַּעַט) upon the spoil.”

upon the carcasses: upon the parts. (Other editions: הַפְּגָרִים is translated into Aramaic as פַּגְלַיָא, [meaning “carcass,” and not “parts,” as Rashi interprets]. But because they [the Targumim] were accustomed to translating אִישׁ בִּתְרוֹ [verse 10] as וִיהַב פַּלְגַּיָא [meaning: “He placed each part”], the word פַּגְלַיָא was mistakenly changed to פַּלְגַּיָא, and they therefore translated הַפְּגָרִים as פַּלְגַיָא. But whoever translates that way is in error, because we cannot equate בְּתָרִים, parts, to פְּגָרִים, carcasses, for בְּתָרִים should be translated פַּלְגַּיָא, and פְּגָרִים should be translated פַּגְלַיָא, an expression of פִּגוּל, an abominable thing, as (Lev. 19:7): “it is an abominable thing (פִּגוּל),” an expression of a carcass. (So I heard from Rabbi Judah the son of Rabbi Samuel.) And so it was emended in a Rashi ms., and in another ms. was written: So did Rabbi Meir the son of Rabbi Samuel explain.)

and Abram drove them away: Heb. וַיַּשֵּׁב, an expression of blowing and causing to fly away, like (Ps. 147:18): “He causes His wind to blow (יַשֵּׁב).” This is an allusion that David the son of Jesse will come to destroy them, but they will not permit him from heaven [to do so] until the King Messiah arrives. [from Pirkei d’Rabbi Eliezer, ch. 28]
But you will come to your forefathers in peace: And you will not witness any of this. [From Gen. Rabbah 44:20]
to your forefathers: His father was an idolater, and He announces to him that he will come to him? This teaches you that Terah repented. [from Tan. Shemoth 18]

you will be buried in a good old age: He announced to him that Ishmael would repent during his lifetime (Gen. Rabbah 30:4, 38:12), and that Esau would not embark on evil ways during his lifetime. Therefore, he died five years before his time, and on that very day, Esau rebelled (ibid. 63:12). See below 25:29f.

And the fourth generation: After they will have been exiled to Egypt, they will be there for three generations, and the fourth will return to this land (Mishnath Rabbi Eliezer ch. 5), for in the land of Canaan He spoke with him, and formed this covenant, as it is written (above verse 7): “to give you this land to inherit it.” And so it was: Jacob descended to Egypt. Go forth and figure his generations: Judah, Perez, and Hezron, and Caleb the son of Hezron was one of those who entered the land (Sotah 11b).

for the iniquity of the Amorites will not be complete: that they should be sent out of their land until that time, for the Holy One, blessed be He, does not punish a nation until its measure is full, as it is said: (Isa. 27:8):“When her measure is full, when You send her away, then You will strive with her.” - [from Zohar, vol. 1, p. 113b]

Now it came to pass that the sun had set: Heb. וַיְהִי הַשֶּׁמֶשׁ בָּאָה. [The subject apparently does not agree with the predicate, because שֶׁמֶשׁ is a feminine noun, whereas וַיְהִי is a masculine verb. Therefore, Rashi explains as follows:] This is similar to (below 42:35): “And it came to pass that they were emptying their sacks”; (II Kings 13:21): “And it came to pass that they were burying a man”; meaning: this event took place. [The subject of וַיְהִי is not הַשֶּׁמֶשׁ but דָבָר זֶה (i.e., it is as if the masculine noun דָבָר זֶה (this event) were inserted after וַיְהִי.] The same is true in the two instances quoted by Rashi, in which the subject is plural, whereas the predicate is singular. There too, the subject of וַיְהִי is דָבָר זֶה.]
the sun had set: Heb. בָּאָה. It had set.
and it was dark: The day darkened.
and behold, a smoldering furnace, etc.: He hinted to him that the kingdoms of the pagans would fall into hell. — [from Pirkei d’Rabbi Eliezer, ch. 28]

had set: Heb. בָּאָה Its accent is on the first syllable. Therefore, it is explained that it had already set; but if its accent were at the end, on the “alef,” it would be explained to mean: as it was setting. but it is impossible to say this, for it is already written (above verse 12): “Now the sun was setting,” and the passing of the smoking furnace happened after this. It is found that it had already set. And this difference exists in every word in the feminine gender, whose radical consists of two letters, such as בא (to come), קם (to arise), שב (to return). When the accent is on the first syllable, it is in the past tense, e.g., this case and e.g., (below 29:9): “and Rachel came (בָּאָה)”; (below 37:7): “my sheaf arose (קָמָה)”; (Ruth 1:15): “Lo! Your sister-in-law has returned (שָׁבָה).” However, when the accent is on the final syllable, it is in the present tense, denoting a thing that is happening now and is continuing to happen, like (below 29:6): “She is coming בָּאָה with the flocks”; (Esther 2:14): “In the evening she would come (בָּאָה), and in the morning she would return (שָׁבָה).”

וירא אליו. [Hashem] appeared to him. To visit the sick (Sotah 14a, Tanchuma Yashan 1). The amora R' Chama the son of Chanina said: It was the third day since his circumcision, and the Holy One, Blessed is He, came and inquired about [Abraham's] welfare.
"she is in the tent"--she was modest
And I am old. The Scripture changed it for peace, for she said: "And my husband is old".

"he will laugh to me" - He will be happy for me. The Midrash Agadah says, "many barren women were remembered with her, many sick were healed on that day, many prayers were answered with her, and much laughter was in the world."
"and he was weaned" - after 24 months (Gitin 75).
"great party" - The greatest individuals of the generation were there: Shem, Ever, and Avimelech.
"Bread and bottle of water" - and not silver and gold because [Avraham] had hatred for him because [Ishmael] went out into a bad culture.
"And the boy" - (Bereishis Rabbah) Even the boy was placed on [Hagai's] shoulder, since Sarah placed in him an evil eye and he got a fever and couldn't walk on his feet.
"And she went and she wandered" - She returned to the idols of her father's house (Bereishis Rabbah).
"The voice of the boy" - From here, [we learn that] the prayer of a sick person is better than the prayers of others on his behalf, since the prayer continues to be received.

"From where he was" - (Rosh HaShanah 16) - Based on the actions that [Ishmael] is doing now, he is considered, and not according to what he will do in the future. This is because the Angels accuse him and say "Creator of the Universe! In the future his offspring will kill your sons through thirst, and you're giving him a well [to drink from]? And [G-d] replies, "now is he a righteous person or a wicked person?" [The Angels] say, "he's a righteous person." (In other words, regarding this matter, [Ishmael] isn't fitting to receive a punishment of death through thirst). [G-d] said to them, "according to the actions of a person now do I judge them....

There are some Sages who say [that this event occurred] “After the words of Satan” who said accusingly [to God], “From all the feasts that Avraham prepared, he did not offer as sacrifice to You a single bull or ram.” He [God] responded to him, “He does everything for the sake of his son. Yet, if I were to say to him, ‘Sacrifice him to Me,’ he would not refuse.” There are those [other Sages] who say “After the words of Yishmael” who would boast to Yitzhak that he was circumcised when he was thirteen and did not resist. Yitzhak responded to him: “You try to intimidate me with one limb. If God would tell me, ‘Sacrifice yourself to Me,’ I would not refuse.”
This is the response of the pious— an expression of humility and readiness.
Na is an expression of a request. He [God] said to him, “I plead with you, withstand this test so that no one can say that the first [tests] were not real.”

He [Avraham] responded, “I have two sons.” He [God] said to him, “Your only one.” He responded, “This one is an only son to his mother and the other is an only son to his mother.” He [God] said to him, “Who you love.” “I love them both,” he [Avraham] answered. Then, He said, “Yitzhak!” Why didn’t God reveal this from the beginning? So as not to confuse him suddenly, and he become bewildered and deranged. And, also, so that he value the mitzvah and he would get the reward for each and every expression.

[This refers to] Jerusalem. As in II Chronicles 3:1, “To build the House of God in Jerusalem on Mount Moriah.” Our rabbis explained [that it is called this] because from there instruction (lit. “Torah”) goes forth to Israel. Onkelos’ translation is based on the incense service which contains myrrh, nard, and other spices.
Return. (He) prophesied two will return
And beheld a ram: (the ram) had been ready since the 6 days of creation

And the life of Sarah was one hundred years and twenty years and seven years: The reason that the word “years” was written after every digit is to tell you that every digit is to be expounded upon individually: when she was one hundred years old, she was like a twenty-year-old regarding sin. Just as a twenty-year-old has not sinned, because she is not liable to punishment, so too when she was one hundred years old, she was without sin. And when she was twenty, she was like a seven-year-old as regards to beauty. — from Gen. Rabbah 58:1]
The years of the life of Sarah: All of them equally good.

To mourn for Sarah and to weep for her. And Sarah's death relied on the Binding of Isaac, because the Binding which almost slaughter her son, but did not slaughter him, took her soul from her and she died.

under my thigh: (Shev. 38) Since one who swears must take with his hand an article related to a mitzvah such as a Torah scroll or Tefillin, and circumcision was his first mitzvah, and he had fulfilled it with pain, it was dear to him; so he took it.
Because he saw that the waters had risen to meet her.
And [Laban] ran. Why did he run and for what did he run? "And it came to pass, when he saw the ring," he said 'this man is rich,' and he focused his eyes on the money.

Perhaps the woman will not follow me: It [the word אֻלַי (perhaps)] is written [without a“vav” and may be read] אֵלַי (to me). Eliezer had a daughter, and he was looking for a pretext so that Abraham would tell him, to turn to him, to marry off his daughter to him (Isaac). Abraham said to him,“My son is blessed, and you are cursed [Eliezer was a descendant of Canaan who had been cursed by Noah], and an accursed one cannot unite with a blessed one.”
She said, "I will go". By myself, even if they don't want me to go.

The tent of his mother, Sarah: He brought her to Sarah's tent and she recreated the likeness of Sarah, as if to say she was like Sarah his mother. As long as Sarah was alive there was a candle lit from Erev Shabbat to Erev Shabbat, there was a blessing found in the dough and a protective cloud attached to the tent. When she died they left, and when Rivka entered they reappeared.
Yaakov and Eisav who are spoken of (further on) in the passage
... it is spelled as "gaayim" i.e."the proud ones". These are Antoninus and Rebbi, for neither radish nor lettuce ceased to be found on their tables during the sunny or rainy season.

My statutes: Things that the evil inclination and the nations of the world oppose, such as eating pig or wearing "mingled together" (sha'atnez), where there is no reason for the thing except the decree of the King and His statutes for His servants.
1 I am Esav your firstborn. I am the one bringing to you, and Esav is your firstborn.
2. I have done. Many things, as you told me.
3. Sit. An expression of reclining on the table, and therefore the Targum renders "estachar."
"And it was told to Rivkah" - Through divine inspiration it was told to her what Esav thought in his heart.
Padenah:  As in, "le-Padan" ["to Padan"].
Beitah Betuel [To the house of Bethuel]:  "Le-veit Betuel" ["to the house of Bethuel"].  Any word that requires a "lamed" at its beginning, a "hei" was placed for it at its end.

"And [he] left" — It was only necessary to write "And Jacob travelled to Charan", so why does it mention his departure? It tells us that the departure of a righteous person from a place makes a mark, because when a righteous person is in a city, he is its glory, he is its radiance, he is its beauty. When he leaves there, the glory departs, the radiance departs, the beauty departs. And similarly (in Ruth 1) "and she left from the place" which is said about Naomi and Ruth.
"And he travelled to Charan" — he left to travel to Charan.

...He set them in the form of a gutter-pipe surrounding his head, since he feared the wild animals. The rocks began arguing with each other, each one stating "upon me should the righteous one lay his head". Hashem joined all of them into one rock, as the verse states, "and he took the rock that he had placed".
And I did not know. For if I had known, I would not have slept in such a holy place as this.

"The eyes of Leah were soft".  For she supposed that she would be fated to become Esau's [wife] and she wept. For everyone used to say: "Rebecca has two two sons; Lavan has two daughters - the older [daughter] for the older [son] and the younger [daughter] for the younger [son]."
This time, I will thank: since I have taken more than my share. Consequently, I must offer up thanks. — [from Gen. Rabbah 71:4]
Rachel envied her sister: She envied her her good deeds. She said, "If she wasn't more righteous than me, she wouldn't have merited to have sons."
Give me: "And did your father act thus to your mother? Didn't he pray over her?"
I die: From here, [we know] that one who has no children is considered like deceased.
neither good or bad.  Even the good of evil persons is considered evil with the righteous.
1 shall not live.  And it was from this very curse that Rachel died along the way.
'He was afraid' that he [Esau] might kill him [Jacob] and he was 'distressed' that he [Esau] might kill others.
"And Jacob remained".  He had forgotten [some] small vessels, and returned for them.

no… Jacob: It shall no longer be said that the blessings came to you through trickery (עָקְבָה) and deceit, but with nobility and openness, and ultimately, the Holy One, blessed be He, will reveal Himself to you in Beth-el and change your name, and there He will bless you, and I will be there.“ He then acknowledged them (the blessings) as being his (Jacob’s). This is [the meaning of] what is written (Hos. 12:5): ”He strove with an angel and prevailed over him; he wept and supplicated him,“ [meaning that] the angel wept and supplicated him. With what did he supplicate him? ”In Beth-el he will find Him, and there He will speak with us“ (ibid). Wait for me until He speaks with us there. Jacob, however, did not consent, [to release the angel] and, against his (the angel’s) will, he (the angel) acknowledged them (the blessings) as being his (Jacob’s). This is [the meaning of] ”And he blessed him there," that he entreated him to wait, but he did not wish [to do so]. — [from Zohar, vol. 3, 45a]
"And he hugged him-" His mercy was aroused (lit. rolled) when he saw him bowing down all of these bows.

"And he kissed him-" There are dots upon it, and there is an argument in this matter in the Braita (Tannaitic teachings outside the Mishnah) of Sifri, Beha'alotcha 69. There are those who expound the dots to mean that he did not kiss him with all his heart. Rabbi Shimon the son of Yochai said, "It is plainly known that Esau hated Jacob, but his mercy was aroused in this moment and he kissed him with all his heart."

And he lay.  In the midst that he disturbed his bed, Scripture accounts it to him as if he had sexual relations with her.  And why did he disturb his bed?  That when Rachel died, Jacob removed his bed that had been regularly in the tent of Rachel and not in the other tents and he placed in the tent of Bilhah.  Reuben came and saw this as an insult to his mother.  He said, " If my mother's sister was my mother's rival, why then would the handmaid of my mother's sister, become my mother's rival?  For this, he disturbed (the bed).

Any bad which he saw in his brothers the children of Leah he told his father. [He told Jacob] they ate from a living animal, that they insulted the sons of the maids (Bilha and Zilpa) calling them slaves, and that they were suspected of illicit relationships and was punished with all three. For [saying that they] ate from a living animal, they slaughtered a goat when they sold him and did not eat it alive. For slandering them that they called their brothers slaves, he was sold as a slave and for the sexual slanders, his masters wife laid eyes on him etc.

Son of old age...for he was born to him at the time of his old age, but Onkelos translated: "wise son," all that he learned from Shem and Ever he passed to him.  Another explanation: his appearance was like his, similar to him.

פסים. expression for garment of fine wool, like“green wool (כַּרְפַּס) and blue” (Esther 1:6), and like the k'tonet passim of Tamar and Amnon (2 Sam. 13:18). But Midrash Agadah references his troubles,  that he was sold to Potiphar , to the sochrim, to the Yishmaelim, and to the Midyanim.
"And Midianite men passed by". This refers to a diferent caravan, and [therefore] the verse is informing you that he was sold multiple times.
"and they pulled". The sons of Jacob [pulled] Joseph from the pit and sold him to Ishmaelites, and the Ishmaelites [sold him] to the Midianites, and the Midianites [sold him] to the Egyptians.
...She was being brought out: to be burned.

Avrech. According to the Targum (onkelos): "father of the king". Rach is king in Aramaic. In (Bava Batra 4a): "[Herod is] not the king nor the son of a king". In the words of the aggadata, R Yehuda says: "Avrech is Yosef, because he was the master (av) of wisdom but short (rach) in years." R. Yose said to him: "until when will you corrupt the scriptures for us? Avrech is only the word for knee, because everyone would enter and exit under his hand, as it is stated "and they appointed him..."

(2) "From the praises of the land" -- From [the translation known as] Targum, "from the praised [produce] of the land," that all [of the praised produce] praises [the land of Israel] when it comes into the world.
"Come to me" - He saw them backing away and told himself "Now my brothers are embarrassed." He called to them in soothing language and showed them that he was circumcised.
"And I, when I came from Padan", etc. - Even though I am burdening you with [the task of] bringing me to Canaan, even though I did not do the same for your mother, whom I buried near Bet Lechem...
He wanted to reveal the end of days and the Divine Presence left him, so he began saying other matters.
"to embalm his father"- meaning, with the spreading of the special salts used by the embalmers
And they filled for him.  They completed for him the days of embalming until he was filled, forty days.
And Egypt wept for seventy days.  Forty for embalming, and thirty for weeping, because blessing came to them, and the famine was forgotten, and the waters of the Nile were blessed.

Which I dug.  Literally, as in Exodus 21:33, "If a man digs", and as the Midrash says it is like "I bought".  Rabbi Akiva said that when he went to seaside cities, it meant "to sell".  Another Midrash says it is derived from the word "a stack", Jacob burdened himself with all the silver and gold that he brought from Lavan's house and made a stack, and he said to Esau "take this for your share of the cave".

As you swore to him.  And if it was not for the sworn oath, Pharoah would not allow this.  However, Pharoah was afraid to say this, because Joseph would break the oath he swore to Pharoah that he would not reveal that he speaks Hebrew and all 70 languages, while Pharoah cannot even understand Hebrew, as written in Tractate Sotah, Page 36B.

Threshing floor of bramble.  It was surrounded, and our Rabbis interpret this to mean that all the kings and princes of Ishmael came to Cana'an for war, and when they saw Jacob's crown on Jacob's coffin they stood and hung their crowns surrounding the coffin like a threshing floor surrounded by thorns.
As he commanded.  What is is that he commanded?
